content: the ground in walls of this location have become the flesh of South OGG and
its iCore spreads at an alarming rate
hey guys welcome back a black magic craft a couple weeks ago I had just
returned home from my trip to the mace convention in the States and I realized
that I had a game of D&D scheduled that I had not planned at all so I had to
very quickly come up with a cool game in a very short period of time
and I kind of panicked but after the initial panic had worn off I set to work
coming up with a cool idea for a game and I had just wrapped up running both
of the frozen King from absolute tabletop and I needed a fresh start so I
figured why not just keep going with some of their work and to be clear any
of the videos I've made where I talk about absolute tables up are in are not
sponsored by them I'm just a really big fan they're friends of mine
and I love using their modules because they're not really modules they're
actually adventure kits they're just books full of ideas and inspiration and
tables and encounters and monsters and things that you can stitch together in
any number of ways to create your own adventures really free form it's
basically just a big book of inspiration and that's exactly the kind of thing
that I need as a DM so I figured I might as well give their most recent adventure
kit a shot it's called shadows over drift chapel and I'm not gonna go into
great detail about what it's about essentially it's kind of a Lovecraftian
sort of horror module set in a maritime community with lots of weird creepy
things it reminds me a lot of the movie Dagon which was one of my favorite
movies as a teenager so I got wrapped up pretty quickly in the ethos here and one
the encounters that they have in here that I really wanted to run was this
thing called the elder thing essentially a cosmic being has crossed over into the
material plane and has transformed the area into its own fleshy self it's super
weird and this really isn't an encounter it's definitely not combat it's more of
a skills check where the player characters just have to leave with their
mind still in one piece it revolves around a lot of sanity and madness
checks and these checks if they were to fail a bunch of them would have very
serious permanent repercussions for the players characters and this really would
mostly be a theater of the mind encounter there's no combat really don't
need a grid or measurements or any spatial reasoning this could absolutely
all be done vocally through roleplay I really wanted to set the tone for this
encounter and how crazy and weird and gross and serious it was with a cool bit
of terrain just to get people in the mood I set to work building this
disgusting tile having very little time I didn't bother planning anything I just
grabbed some foam and got to work and I knew I had to ignore details and design
and just had to get creative as quickly as possible this was only a few days
after competing and losing against diem Scotty in the guild master build off at
mace so I took direct influence from the craft master and went for some simple
foam carving using my handheld hot wire cutter I made a small ground tile and
used the scrap pieces to make up the back wall I went with what is now my
favorite method for these sorts of encounter pieces and did just enough
back and sidewall to represent what it looks like while leaving the rest open
for easier line of sight for the players I really really roughly placed some
scrap pieces together to form the back wall not worrying too much about gaps or
anything like that I just wildly glued them into place then I was able to take
my hot wire and start carving walls and a bit of the bass at the same
time to tie them together a little bit better the back of this piece didn't
matter too much as the players wouldn't really see it but I wanted it to look
decent nonetheless my initial thought process on this build was that I'd make
it look like a cave or cellar as the encounter was to take place in the
basement I figured I'd make it mostly look like stone and then I'd add some
gross fleshy effects in order to look like the Eldar thing was slowly taking
over and transforming the space for this reason I textured the foam with aluminum
foil to give it a stone effect and taking inspiration from the art in the
adventure kit I drew out some magical looking symbols again the idea being
that maybe the stone building was transforming I thought these runes could
be carved in and painted to look like they were using blood or something like
that once I had my basic symbols drawn I used a hot engraving tool to melt the
foam and create the actual grooves I find this tool to be too big and
aggressive for detail working foam like bricks or something but it's perfect for
this I actually had a lot of fun doing this and went a bit crazy covering the
whole thing with made-up letters from some ancient language I really wanted
this room to look crazy to more easily play on the madness element of the
skills challenge after progressing with this build almost all of this work would
end up covered and not visible but it was still fun and a worthwhile exercise
to try this out I went to work with hot glue creating the flesh spawn effects if
I didn't need this piece completed in a few hours I probably would have opted to
instead do this effect with toilet paper and PVA glue but that takes ages to dry
I needed something that would be ready to paint in minutes so that I could get
this thing on the game table the next day so hot glue is almost always the
solution in a scenario like this it's really easy to do these sorts of effects
with the glue gun the real challenge is not going overboard which is what I
absolutely did one of the problems with hot glue is
that it's hard to paint almost impossible with craft paint and a brush
so I opted to use some spray primer on the piece and I chose white because I
knew I wanted to create a pinky flesh and guts effect on all the hot glue and
white is a better base coat for these sorts of colors there's a lot of raw
exposed foam on this piece but as I mentioned last video I have practiced
spray-painting foam enough and tested enough brands to know I could do this
safely also in the off chance something did melt it would blend right into this
crazy piece but as you can see on the back which is exposed foam there was no
problem practice and test practice and test then you can spray-paint foam
confidently looking at this thing I realized it would be really damn
difficult to paint it in a combination of stone and flesh it could be done but
it would be a time-consuming and tedious task I simply didn't have that kind of
time to spare I had to blast this thing with paint and I couldn't afford to be
diplomatic about it so I just said screw it and covered the whole thing in a
light peach color and thankfully this covered really well and I only needed
one coat next I grabbed a lighter version of the same color and went in
and started hitting some of the higher areas those aren't really a dry brush
because the paint was still wet this was really just a frantic and chaotic
dabbing exercise in futility I'm not sure this step did anything meaningful
at all but again I wasn't thinking I was just doing and I think that's a very
healthy approach to take sometimes this is where things started to go south
because I wasn't thinking I grabbed some red and just went to town slapped it on
everything in a sort of dry brush highlight fashion man did this look
awful I knew it was bad but I just kept going in the hopes that if I kept
putting enough paint and stuff on the piece it would eventually look cool it
was also at this point I realized all the symbols that I had carved in were
basically invisible especially the little ones this was followed by another
poor decision and horrible execution of adding some blue to create some veins or
arteries I always forget which one looks blue and
honestly I don't care enough to look it up right now but you know what I'm
getting at this red-and-blue probably could have looked good if I had put in
any effort to do it nicely but I didn't I literally painted all of this in about
two minutes but that was the theme of this build
shotgun crafting honestly though it really looked like crap so I put on
another coat of the light peachy color I applied this pretty thin so that some of
the blue and red still showed through and I think this actually did make an
interesting look that was starting to get this thing where I wanted it to go
and that's when things got really experimental and I started to go crazy
with it I needed this paint to dry fast so that
I could put on a wash so I broke out my heat gun I knew this would come with
risk it would likely make paint bubble reheat and distort the hot glue and
possibly melt some foam but this project was the perfect place to take that risk
actually after seeing it start to do some of these things I knew I was on to
the thing that would save this project I went with it and let it melt and bubble
stuff then I mixed up a red wash using some airbrush thinner flow improver and
some matte medium using some red acrylic paint for the color I absolutely would
have preferred red ink but I don't have any and I wasn't shy about putting this
on either I just completely covered the thing and hoped for the best
I started to feel a bit ballsy so I dripped on some other washes first some
brown and then some black I even used some toxic looking neon green ink at
this point I was really just throwing all caution and reason to the wind and
going wild and I got to tell you it was really liberating and exciting to do so
it brought back a lot of the excitement from the early days in the hobby though
they seem to have lost while worrying about making things look nicer I let all
the washes and ink flow and mixed naturally creating a really gross pile
like mess it looked pretty cool but drying was a problem so I again busted
out the heat gun to see what it would do this got really fun the heap caused
everything to distort and bubble even more it was really starting to look like
the face of Freddy Krueger or something and it created some really amazing
bubbles but I knew these bubbles were Hollow and wouldn't be stable so I used
a brush to push all the reheated glue back down onto the foam to bond again at
this point I was pretty happy with how this thing was looking certainly the
most vile creation I've ever made in this hobby well maybe I'm not sure I've
made a couple pretty gross projects but you know what would make it even better
pus yep I figured some pus oozing out of a few places would just add to the
disgusting nature of this piece to achieve this I watered down some
modeling paste and just dripped it on in a few select places this didn't work as
well as I had hoped but I really didn't have the time to test out other
techniques so I just ran with it the white was too bright though it looked
really out of place a few dabs of sepia wash after the pus had dried did the
trick nicely this wasn't just bodily fluid it was
disgusting diseased bodily fluid I'm telling you I wanted my players to
really feel the madness of the situation the last thing I did on the build was
add a coat of Mod Podge and I never put Mod Podge on as a final coat but I
figured it would be perfect here I wanted it to look wet and slimy so some
gloss Mod Podge would be perfect I put it on really heavy and I didn't worry
about brushing off the excess I actually intentionally put on too much
and overworked it causing a frothy bubbly mess I didn't know how this would
drive on a normal piece this would obviously be bad but I figured on this
one if those bubbles stayed and parts of it
looked a bit white it might look cool so I put it on like a maniac
and let the thing dry overnight I knew that whatever I was left with would be
what I had to work with in the next day's game and you know what it turned
out awesome I honestly couldn't be happier with it this thing performed
beautifully in game my players loved it and were seriously disturbed by both the
bizarre callenge and by the gross terrain if I were to do this sort of
thing again I'd honestly go for a similar final result I just know I could
skip some of the early steps that turned out to be irrelevant because of the
later ones you may not want to build a disgusting flesh tile for your game but
I hope you take some inspiration from this regardless specifically I want you
to be inspired to go at a project without any planning and a mind open to
rapid experimentation you might just love what you come up with and at the
very least you'll probably have some fun in the process
I hope you guys enjoyed this video if you did hit the like button and let me
know in the comment section below that sort of interaction really helps these
videos gain momentum and if you want to pick up any tools or supplies for your
own hobby needs especially if you're just getting started I've created a
really good resource on my website Blackmagic craft dot CA I have an
essential equipment page where I list explain and link to all of or at least
most of the stuff that I use regularly so that you can buy the right stuff and
if you get a lot of value out of these videos I make and you want to help me
keep making them one really awesome way you can help me do that is by supporting
the channel on patreon patreon is easily my most reliable and secure revenue
stream for this channel and one of the main reasons I can put out these videos
on a regular basis so if you're into that sort of thing you want to help me
out help me help the community consider joining the fellowship on patreon that's
it for this week guys this is really not that well suited for a holiday season at
so it is it but I mean it is for me this is pretty cool I think that's it for
this week guys Cheers I will see you again next week
